definitions: go beyond the bounds or limits set by a law or rule
break a moral or divine law committing an offense against principles
examples: The company transgressed environmental regulations repeatedly
Students who transgress school rules face suspension
He felt guilty for transgressing his religious beliefs
Those who transgress moral boundaries must face consequences

definitions: gradually weaken or damage someone's power authority or efforts over time
erode the base or foundation of something making it less secure
examples: Constant criticism undermined her confidence completely
These rumors could undermine his political campaign
Water seepage undermined the building's foundation
Erosion continues to undermine the cliff face

definitions: clear someone of blame or suspicion showing they were right
show or prove that something is true justified or reasonable
examples: New evidence vindicated the wrongly accused man
The investigation vindicated her from all charges
Time vindicated his investment strategy
The results vindicated our research methods

definitions: decrease in vigor power or extent becoming weaker or smaller
show a progressively smaller illuminated area after being full
examples: Public interest in the scandal began to wane
Her enthusiasm for the project waned over time
The moon wanes after reaching its fullest phase
Watch the moon wane throughout the month

definitions: formally give up royal power and position as monarch
fail to fulfill or refuse to accept responsibility or duty
examples: The king abdicated in favor of his son
She was forced to abdicate after the revolution
Parents shouldn't abdicate their responsibility to educate children
He abdicated his role as team leader

definitions: scold or criticize someone angrily and at length in harsh terms
examples: The coach berated players for their poor performance
Don't berate yourself for making honest mistakes

definitions: adjust an instrument or device to ensure accurate measurements or performance
examples: Technicians calibrate the equipment before each use
You need to calibrate the scale every month

definitions: kill destroy or remove a large percentage or part of something
examples: The disease decimated the bird population
Budget cuts decimated the arts programs

definitions: issue or spread out from a source flowing forth naturally
examples: A strange smell emanated from the old basement
Confidence emanated from her every gesture

definitions: make an action or process easy or easier by helping it along
examples: The new software facilitates communication between teams
Good planning facilitates project completion

definitions: shock or excite someone into taking action through strong motivation
coat iron or steel with zinc to prevent rusting
examples: The tragedy galvanized the community into action
Her speech galvanized supporters to volunteer
They galvanize steel pipes for outdoor use
The factory galvanizes metal sheets daily

definitions: create difficulties resulting in delay or obstruction of progress
examples: Bad weather hindered the rescue operation
Don't let fear hinder your dreams

definitions: light up something with light making it bright and visible
help to clarify or explain something making it understandable
examples: Candles illuminated the dark hallway
Streetlights illuminate the road at night
The professor illuminated complex theories with simple examples
Her research illuminated previously unknown facts

definitions: throw goods overboard from ship or aircraft to lighten load
abandon or discard something that is no longer wanted hastily
examples: The crew jettisoned cargo to save the sinking ship
Pilots may jettison fuel before emergency landings
The company jettisoned its unprofitable divisions
She jettisoned negative relationships from her life

definitions: criticize someone or something harshly and publicly with strong words
examples: Critics lambasted the film for its poor plot
The press lambasted the politician's decision

definitions: display or show a quality or feeling clearly through actions
become apparent or appear in physical form becoming real
examples: Her anxiety manifested in nervous habits
The disease manifests through various symptoms
His anger manifested as aggressive behavior
Dreams sometimes manifest into reality

definitions: plan and direct the route or course of a ship aircraft or vehicle
find one's way through a difficult or complicated situation successfully
examples: The captain navigated through dangerous waters
Use GPS to navigate to your destination
She navigated the complex legal system alone
Learning to navigate office politics takes time

definitions: destroy utterly wiping out all traces leaving nothing remaining
examples: The explosion obliterated the abandoned building
Time had obliterated all evidence of the settlement

definitions: die especially in a violent or sudden way or be destroyed
examples: Many soldiers perished in the battle
Food will perish without proper refrigeration

definitions: express or measure the quantity of something using numbers or amounts
examples: It's difficult to quantify the impact of education
Scientists quantify pollution levels in the river

definitions: voluntarily give up or surrender possession power control or rights
examples: He refused to relinquish control of the company
She relinquished her claim to the inheritance

definitions: cause something to become thoroughly soaked with liquid unable to absorb more
fill something completely to capacity leaving no room for more
examples: Rain saturated the soil after the drought
The sponge was saturated with soapy water
Advertisements saturate television during prime time
The market is saturated with similar products

definitions: shorten something by cutting off the top end or a part
examples: The editor truncated the article to fit the space
They had to truncate the meeting due to time

definitions: make practical and effective use of something for a purpose
examples: The company utilizes renewable energy sources
Teachers utilize technology to enhance learning

definitions: check or prove the validity accuracy or truth of something
make or declare something legally valid or officially acceptable
examples: Research validates our initial hypothesis
Please validate your parking ticket at the desk
The court will validate the contract tomorrow
You need to validate your passport before traveling

definitions: refrain from insisting on or using a right claim or privilege
examples: She waived her right to a lawyer
The bank waived the overdraft fee

definitions: set or declare someone free from blame guilt or responsibility
examples: The priest absolved him of his sins
Evidence absolved her from any wrongdoing

definitions: support or strengthen something making it more effective or substantial
examples: Additional evidence bolstered their case
Exercise helps bolster your immune system

definitions: come together and form one mass or whole combining separate elements
examples: The droplets coalesced into larger drops
Different groups coalesced to form the movement

definitions: set the boundaries or limits of something clearly marking separation
examples: The fence demarcates our property from theirs
Rules demarcate acceptable behavior in class

definitions: contemplate or conceive of something as a possibility in the future
examples: I can't envisage living anywhere else
They envisage expansion into new markets

definitions: prevent or obstruct something by taking action ahead of time
examples: Quick action forestalled a major crisis
They raised prices to forestall competition

definitions: extract information from various sources collecting it gradually and carefully
examples: She gleaned important details from the report
Researchers glean data from multiple studies

definitions: be a sign that something is about to happen or announce it publicly
examples: Dark clouds herald an approaching storm
The newspaper heralded the new policy changes

definitions: delay or prevent someone or something by obstructing their progress
examples: Heavy traffic impeded our journey to the airport
Don't let obstacles impede your progress

definitions: place things close together or side by side for comparison or contrast
examples: The artist juxtaposed light and dark colors
The film juxtaposes wealth and poverty effectively

definitions: light or set fire to something causing it to burn
arouse or inspire an emotion or feeling in someone
examples: She kindled the campfire with dry twigs
Use paper to kindle the logs quickly
His words kindled hope in their hearts
The movie kindled her interest in history

definitions: take a claim or dispute to a court of law for resolution
examples: They decided to litigate rather than settle
The company will litigate to protect its patents

definitions: appease someone's anger or anxiety making them less upset or hostile
examples: She tried to mollify the angry customer
His apology mollified her hurt feelings

definitions: care for and encourage the growth or development of someone or something
examples: Parents nurture their children with love and attention
Teachers nurture students' creative talents

definitions: move or swing back and forth in a regular rhythm
vary or fluctuate between extremes of opinion action or quality
examples: The pendulum oscillated with perfect timing
The fan oscillates to distribute air evenly
He oscillated between hope and despair
Prices oscillate based on market conditions

definitions: make someone less angry or hostile by doing something to please them
examples: The manager tried to placate upset customers
Offering refunds helped placate their complaints

definitions: satisfy one's thirst by drinking liquid relieving dryness
extinguish a fire or light by dousing with water
examples: Cold water quenched his thirst after exercise
Nothing quenches thirst better than fresh lemonade
Firefighters worked to quench the blazing building
Rain quenched the forest fire naturally

definitions: revoke cancel or repeal a law order or agreement officially
examples: The government rescinded the controversial law
They rescinded the job offer after background checks

definitions: support an organization or activity financially with money grants or tax breaks
examples: The government subsidizes farmers during droughts
Many countries subsidize renewable energy projects

definitions: be virtually the same as or equivalent to something in effect
examples: His silence was tantamount to admission of guilt
Refusing to vote is tantamount to giving up your voice

definitions: show someone to their seat or position guiding them politely
cause or mark the start of something new or significant
examples: The attendant ushered guests to their tables
Volunteers usher people into the concert hall
The invention ushered in a new technological era
Spring ushers in warmer weather and new growth
